content.raw: I did this on purpose. I wanted to scale the reference visual so that it consumes the same amount of screen space. A statically sized reference visual can take up the entire screen when zoomed in close, or be near invisible when zoomed far out. Scaling the reference visual alleviates this problem.
content.html: I did this on purpose. I wanted to scale the reference visual so that it consumes the same amount of screen space. A statically sized reference visual can take up the entire screen when zoomed in close, or be near invisible when zoomed far out. Scaling the reference visual alleviates this problem.

content.raw: I just noticed that the orbit appears to have the same number of pixels allocated to it, no matter how far away it is from the camera. This makes it seem big when far away and small up close. Not a show-stopper, but it's a little disorienting.
content.html: I just noticed that the orbit appears to have the same number of pixels allocated to it, no matter how far away it is from the camera. This makes it seem big when far away and small up close. Not a show-stopper, but it's a little disorienting.

content.raw:
1. I've added some more logic to help with this case. If nothing is under the mouse, then the reference visual is project 10m in front of the camera. If the resulting motion is too slow, then you can hold control and the speed should double (roughly).

2. Fixed.

3. Fixed.
content.html:
1. I've added some more logic to help with this case. If nothing is under the mouse, then the reference visual is project 10m in front of the camera. If the resulting motion is too slow, then you can hold control and the speed should double (roughly).

  2. Fixed.

  3. Fixed.

pull_request.title: Implemented orbit around an arbitrary point

pullrequest.title: Implemented orbit around an arbitrary point

content.raw:
I agree with Thomas that it does work much better now. A couple comments:

1. If your cursor is not pointing at an object when you click (ie. pointing at the sky or past the edge of the ground plane when zoomed out very far), then the orbit doesn't attach to an object and panning and zooming are really slow. Rotate seems to work with the center at the current camera position, so that no camera translation occurs, which I find pretty useful. Wouldn't mind a keyboard shortcut for that behavior (Shift + Center click drag or something).

2. The camera behavior is different when the rotate / move tools are selected. It basically locks the previous orb location in place until you return to the Selection tool. This also resembles an accidental feature, in case people wanted the orb location to hold still across a couple of click+drags, though I'm not sure how useful that feature is.

3. Sometimes I like to adjust the camera to get a top-down view of the world. This used to work, though there was a little bit of weird camera rotation because of the singularity in yaw-pitch-roll rotations when pitch = +- 90 degrees. With this pull request, however, it lets you rotate past the singularity so that the camera is upside down, which is kind of awesome, though I suspect it's unintended. I can supply a video if people are having trouble reproducing this. Maybe we should limit the maximum pitch angles to +-89 degrees or something like that?
content.html:
I agree with Thomas that it does work much better now. A couple comments:

  1. If your cursor is not pointing at an object when you click (ie. pointing at the sky or past the edge of the ground plane when zoomed out very far), then the orbit doesn't attach to an object and panning and zooming are really slow. Rotate seems to work with the center at the current camera position, so that no camera translation occurs, which I find pretty useful. Wouldn't mind a keyboard shortcut for that behavior (Shift + Center click drag or something).

  2. The camera behavior is different when the rotate / move tools are selected. It basically locks the previous orb location in place until you return to the Selection tool. This also resembles an accidental feature, in case people wanted the orb location to hold still across a couple of click+drags, though I'm not sure how useful that feature is.

  3. Sometimes I like to adjust the camera to get a top-down view of the world. This used to work, though there was a little bit of weird camera rotation because of the singularity in yaw-pitch-roll rotations when pitch = +- 90 degrees. With this pull request, however, it lets you rotate past the singularity so that the camera is upside down, which is kind of awesome, though I suspect it's unintended. I can supply a video if people are having trouble reproducing this. Maybe we should limit the maximum pitch angles to +-89 degrees or something like that?

content.raw:
Nice, works much better now, thanks! Fixes issues #116, #241, and #267.

One improvement might be to use models' visual mesh for ray-tracing the focal point instead of the bounding box (seems like that's what's currently being used). Currently this behaviour prevents you from clicking a point on the model or to click on a point behind the model (e.g. the ground on the other side of the polaris ranger).
content.html:
Nice, works much better now, thanks! Fixes issues #116, #241, and #267.

One improvement might be to use models' visual mesh for ray-tracing the focal point instead of the bounding box (seems like that's what's currently being used). Currently this behaviour prevents you from clicking a point on the model or to click on a point behind the model (e.g. the ground on the other side of the polaris ranger).
